So on this Constitution Day, let us celebrate the wisdom of the founders who penned our enduring document of self-governance, but also redouble our efforts to ensure that we continue to expand constitutional rights to all Americans to live their own lives of freedom.

üßµ As we celebrate Constitution Day, let‚Äôs pause to reflect on the fact that women today have fewer rights today than they did on this day last year. For the first time in our history, the Supreme Court has ripped away rights enjoyed by women for 50 years.

The Museum is named after Richard Allen, founder of the first African-American Episcopal Church in the US.

The Richard Allen Cultural Center and Museum in Leavenworth is a great place to learn more about #BlackHistoryMonth in #KS02. The museum is located in the former home of Buffalo Soldier and US Army Captain William Bly.
Their home served as an Underground Railroad station home and paved the way for Kansas to become a free state.
To learn more about the Ritchie House as well as John and Mary‚Äôs legacy, visit https://t.co/sjxPJ08pGX

The Historic Ritchie House is located in Topeka. The home is named after John and Mary Ritchie who settled in Topeka in 1855. John helped write the free-state constitution and founded Washburn University.

Rest in Peace Sen. Dole. We'll do our best to carry on in your absence.
It was a bipartisan accomplishment that helped rural and urban Americans and helped create the largest expansion of the middle class in history.
Partnering with Sen. McGovern, Sen. Dole helped create food nutrition programs that helped feed hungry Americans and helped America's struggling farmers.
Many of those public servants had served together battling the facists in far flung lands, and knew they were working on a common cause, despite their differences.
As we pause today to remember the life and service of former Senator Bob Dole, it's important to remember a time when Democrats and Republicans worked together to for the country.
It‚Äôs our inheritance that we must zealously defend to ensure future generations can enjoy it as we do.
Many like Sen. Dole were grievously wounded or killed. As we remember their sacrifice this Pearl Harbor day, let‚Äôs not forget what they fought for. Democracy, freedom and opportunity.

80 years ago today our nation was attacked and, for us, World War II began. Americans of all stripes and colors answered President Franklin Roosevelt‚Äôs call to action. Kansans, like Sen. Bob Dole fought heroically to defeat our adversaries.

https://t.co/9ThcG9F74v
Today, after being missing for 70 years, Father Kapaun will be laid to rest in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Wichita.

Serving as an Army chaplain in the Korean War, Kapaun and his unit were captured by Chinese forces in 1950 and were held in a prisoner of war camp, where Kapaun sacrificed himself to save other Americans.

My father grew up not too far from the little town of Pilsen in northern Marion County, where in 1950 a young Catholic priest left to serve in the Korean war.  Father Emil Kapaun's life and sacrifice epitomizes Kansas values.
